Unravelling the role of Fe in trimetallic Fe-Cu-Pt/Al2O3 catalysts for CO-PROX reaction Sandra Palma a Miriam González-Castaño a ⁎ Francisca Romero-Sarria a Jose Antonio Odriozola a a Departamento de Química Inorgánica e Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla, Centro mixto Universidad de Sevilla-CSIC, Avda. Américo Vespucio 49, 41092 Sevilla, Spain Departamento de Química Inorgánica e Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla Centro mixto Universidad de Sevilla-CSIC Avda. Américo Vespucio 49 Sevilla 41092 Spain aDepartamento de Química Inorgánica e Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Sevilla, Centro mixto Universidad de Sevilla-CSIC, Avda. Américo Vespucio 49, 41092 Sevilla, Spain ⁎ Corresponding author at: University of Seville: Universidad de Sevilla, Germany. University of Seville: Universidad de Sevilla Germany This work proposes a trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst as an appealing system for preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) reaction. The excellent conversion rates achieved by the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts under realistic reforming-surrogated feed streams along with the catalyst stability, reproducibility, and scalability showcase a very competitive system for CO-PROX reaction units. Furthermore, the systematic analysis conducted for Pt/Al2O3, Cu/Pt Al2O3, and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts enabled establishing meaningful relationships between catalytic behaviour and the catalyst surface to reactants interactions. Thus, the enhanced CO oxidation performances attained by the incorporation of Fe species into bimetallic Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were associated to superior surface electron densities and inhibited CO adsorption process over Pt surfaces. Remarkably, operando-DRIFTS spectroscopy evidenced significantly larger H-containing surface species developed over the trimetallic system. The enhanced abilities for developing thermally instable intermediates favoured by small amounts of Fe should indeed determine the enhanced catalysts behaviours displayed by the trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO-PROX Pt-Cu bimetallic catalysts Fe-Cu-Pt trimetallic catalysts Fe role Operando-DRIFTS 1 Introduction The use of H2 as energy vector has been intimately correlated to the development of fuel cells. Among the different types of fuel cells, Polymer Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFC) present short response times and allow operating at relatively low temperatures facilitating its implementation into domestic or portable devices [1]. For PEMFC, it is important to warranty high purity H2 feeds with CO concentrations below 20–50 ppm in order to avoid the poisoning of the Pt anode and prolong the PEMFC life-time [2]. Generally, the H2 streams are generated via reforming reactions where the concomitant presence of COx and H2O as subproducts is expected. Therefore, purification units prior the PEMFC are required so the CO concentration is diminished up to suitable levels. With the composition of H2-containing mixtures depending on the source, employing biomethanol arises as a particularly appealing option since the low concentrations of CO obtained simplify the subsequent purification stages by removing the Water Gas Shift reaction unit [3]. Thus, once the hydrogen is produced via methanol steam reforming, a single unit of Preferential Oxidation of CO (CO-PROX, CO + ½ O2 + H2⟶ CO2 + H2) reaction could attain the H2 composition requirements imposed by PEMFC [4]. Remarkably, the decrease of the CO content ought to proceed without affecting significantly the H2 concentration within gas mixtures containing H2, CO2, H2O, CO [5]. A priori, an efficient catalyst for CO-PROX reaction should be highly active for the CO oxidation while exhibiting minimum tendencies towards oxidizing H2 molecules[6]. The catalysts should be also capable of operating in presence of CO2 and H2O at relatively low temperatures in order to promote the integration of the CO-PROX unit in the process since PEMFC operates between 80 and 200 °C [7]. Cu catalysts stands one of the best choices since, remaining cost-effective, display comparable performances than noble metals while exhibiting larger resistances to H2O and CO2 species [8,9]. For Cu catalysts, the incorporation of a second metal is known to improve the catalyst activity and selectivity towards CO2. For CO-PROX reaction, a Langmuir−Hinshelwood pathway where the reaction proceeds through the interaction of co-adsorbed O2 and CO molecules has been proposed with the oxygen adsorption described as the rate-limiting step [10]. This dual-site reaction mechanism has been validated via Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations by Pan et al.[11] for Pt-M alloys. The promotion of the Cu catalyst performances by constituting Cu-M interfaces is generally based on the establishment of a non-competitive reaction mechanism for CO and O2 species where the CO and O2 adsorptions proceed through different active sites [12–14]. For Cu-Pt bimetallic catalysts, it is then proposed that the CO adsorption will take place over Pt surfaces whilst the O2 adsorption will mostly occur over Cu surfaces. Therefore, the higher CO-PROX reaction rates achieved by Pt-Cu systems is attributed to the incorporation of additional O2 activation sites with the subsequent promotion of the CO-PROX rate limiting step. Besides, the constitution of Cu-Pt interfaces is also reported to increase the CO-PROX reaction rate due to the altered redox and electronic properties established within Cu-Pt alloys [13] where the electron donation from Cu to Pt result in weaker Pt-CO and Pt-H2 adsorptions. Gómez et al.[15] recently demonstrated that the incoporation of low amounts of Pt (0.2 – 0.5 wt.%) over Cu/Al2O3 resulted in well performing CO-PROX catalysts. On the other hand, similar benefits have been reported by incorporating iron oxide into Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [16] in which the Fe species increase the electron density of nearby Pt particles favouring the CO oxidation rate. For Pt-Fe systems, the enhanced CO oxidation performances has been related to favoured CO and O2 adsorptions at the Pt-Fe interface [17–19]. Besides, the presence of iron might also enhance the CO oxidation rate via oxygen spillover effects from Fe to Pt sites where CO molecules are activated. The intrinsic ability towards CO oxidation processes characteristic of Fe species might explain the optimal catalysts performances achieved for Pt-M bimetallic particles supported over γ-Fe2O3 for CO-PROX [20–22]. From the benefits argued for Pt-Cu and Pt-Fe catalysts and the patent registered using the combination of these three metals[22], this work proposes an active and stable γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst based in (10 wt.%) Cu and (2 wt.%) Pt and (0.5 wt.%) Fe for CO-PROX reaction. Considering the complexity of the trimetallic system and aiming to understand the effect of the individual and simultaneous addition of Cu and Fe oxides over Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, a bottom-up strategy in which a series of catalysts comprising Pt/γ-Al2O3, Cu/Pt/γ-Al2O3, Fe/Pt/γ-Al2O3, and Fe-Cu/Pt/γ-Al2O3 were investigated. Following this bottom-up approach, this work bypasses to some extent the inconvenients of trimetallic systems associated to their high complexity and poor reproducibility. The main objective and novelty of this work is to understand the improvement on the catalytic activity obtained in CO-PROX reaction when trimetallic Fe-Cu-Pt catalysts are employed. The significantly improved catalyst performance displayed by the trimetallic catalyst was found to be related to the Pt-Cu and Pt-Fe interactions which, according to operando-FTIR spectroscopy, enables higher CO conversion rates within low-temperature ranges by establishing surface species with lower thermal stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis For this work, a four catalysts series consisting of Pt/γ-Al2O3, Cu/Pt/γ-Al2O3, Fe/Pt/γ-Al2O3, and Fe-Cu/Pt/γ-Al2O3 were prepared using Cu(NO3)2•6H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 98%), Fe(NO3)2•9H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99%), Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 (Jonshon Mattey, 2.468%) as metal precursors and mesoporous γ-Al2O3 (Sasol) as support. The nominal metal contents intended for the catalysts were 10 wt.% Cu, 2 wt.% Pt and 0.5 wt.% Fe. For all catalysts, Pt metal was firstly dry impregnated over the γ-Al2O3 support using a Pt to acetic acid molar ratio of 1 [23]. The obtained dried solid (overnight at 120 °C) was divided in 4 fractions with one of them leading to the bare (2 wt.%)Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst after calcination and the other three to be employed for the subsequent impregnation of Cu and Fe metals. For bimetallic and trimetallic systems, adequate amounts of Cu and Fe metal precursors were dissolved in aqueous solutions and wetness impregnated over the dried Pt alumina solid (prior calcination). The excess of solvent was removed under reduced pressure in a rotatory evaporator. The obtained solids were dried overnight and subsequently calcined at 300 °C during 8 h using a 10 °C/min heating ramp. For sake of conciseness, the prepared catalysts: (2 wt.%) Pt/γ-Al2O3; (10 wt.%) Cu/(2 wt.%) Pt/γ-Al2O3; (0.5 wt.%) Fe /(2 wt.%) Pt/γ-Al2O3; and (0.5 wt.%) Fe – (10 wt.%) Cu/(2 wt.%) Pt/γ-Al2O3 were labelled Pt/Al, Cu/Pt/Al, Fe/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al, correspondingly. 2.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity was evaluated at 120 L/gh employing a fixed-bed tubular reactor (internal diameter: 9 mm) and 100 mg of catalysts. The catalytic tests were conducted simulating the gas mixture surrogated from a methanol steam reforming unit. Thus, the employed feed stream was composed by 50% H2, 0.25% CO, 17% CO2, 0.38% O2, 15% H2O and N2 balance (λ = 2xO2/CO = 3). The stability and synthesis scalability of the best performing sample was evaluated employing the former reaction atmosphere. The effect of λ was evaluated using a feed stream composed by 1%CO + X%O2 + 50%H2 + 17%CO2 + 10%H2O + N2-Balanced with X= 0.5 – 1 – 1.5% O2. Moreover, the impact of the concentration of H2O was evaluated employing feed streams composed by 0.25%CO + 0.38%O2 + 50%H2 + 17%CO2 + X%H2O + N2-Balanced with X= 0 – 5 – 10 – 15 – 30% H2O. Prior the catalytic tests, the catalysts were pre-activated under reaction feed streams in absence of oxygen at 200 °C (15 °C/min) during 90 min. The gas mixtures composition was analysed using a ®Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph suited with two columns ®Porapak Q and ®Molsieve 5A. The CO conversion and O2 selectivity to CO2 formation values were estimated according to Eqs. (1) and 2, respectively: (Eq. 1) % C O c o n v e r s i o n = [ C O ] i n − [ C O ] o u t [ C O ] i n x 100 2.3 Characterisation techniques The chemical composition of the samples was analysed by X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) spectrometry conducted in a Panalytical AXIOS PW4400 with Rh source. The textural properties of the samples were evaluated by N2 physisorption carried out in a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 with the samples previously degassed at 150 °C under vacuum during 2 h. XRD data of fresh samples were recorded in an X'Pert Pro-PANalytical instrument over a 2θ range 10–80° using a step size of 0.05° and a step time of 240 s. In-situ XRD measurements were performed in an XPert Pro-Philips equipment suited with a X'Celerator detector and a high temperature camera ANTON PAR HTK 1200. The diffractograms were recorded under 5% H2/N2 mixtures using a step size of 0.05° and an equivalent acquisition time of 1000s. In-situ XRD measurements in H2 presence were recorded using a temperature program in which the samples were: i) heated until 200 °C (15 °C/min) and held 45 min; ii) heated at 300 °C (15 °C/min), dwell 150 min. TEM micrographs of the pre-reduced samples were obtained using a holey carbon-coated copper grid for supporting the samples. Measurements were conducted in a high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) with the images recorded on a JEOL2010F instrument. The HAADF-STEM studies were carried out employing an electron probe of 0.5 nm diameter and a diffraction camera length of 10 cm. The chemical composition of the sample was evaluated in STEM mode using an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (Oxford Instrument, Inca Energy-200). In-situ CO adsorption experiments followed by FTIR spectroscopy were recorded in a Nicolet Avatar 380 FTIR spectrometer suited with a DTGS detector. The spectra were recorded in the 400–4000 cm−1 range at 4 cm−1 resolutions (64 scans accumulation). The samples were pressed into self-supporting disks (ca. 15 mg), placed in a quartz IR cell and treated with hydrogen (100 torr) at 200 °C for 2 h and subsequently, cooled down to room temperature for the CO adsorptions. The reducibility of the samples was evaluated by H2-TPR by using 50 mg of sample sandwiched in a u-shaped quartz reactor. The samples were reduced at 10 °C up to 900 °C under 5%H2/N2 streams. The Reducibility Percentage (RP,%) was estimated by dividing the H2 consumed by the theoretic H2 that should be consumed by all reducible species at their higher oxidation state (PtO, CuO and Fe2O3). For operando FTIR experiments, the catalyst powder was pressed in wafers with a thickness of about 50 μm. The square wafer, a 10.5 × 10.5 mm pellet, was inserted in a specifically designed sample holder with a triangular gas distributor (cone spray) and a triangular collector that was finally introduced in the Sandwich cell described in [24].The cell was then connected to the gas manipulation apparatus, consisting of mass flow controllers in addition to a mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Omnistar GSD 301), an IR gas cell (Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 GC-IR) for the analysis of the gaseous phase leaving the reactor. Infrared spectra (32 scans per spectrum) of both the catalyst and the gas phase were collected with an acquisition frequency of one spectrum every 2.7 s by means of a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FT-IR equipped with an MCT detector. Prior the operando-DRIFTS spectra, the samples were pre-treated under reaction atmospheres during 2 h at 200 °C (15 °C/min) and subsequently degassed at 300 °C under secondary vacuum (10−5 bar). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical composition and textural properties The chemical composition and the textural properties exhibited by the prepared catalysts are presented in Table 1 . Remarkably close to nominal Cu, Pt and Fe metal contents were obtained for all synthetized samples. Table 1 also summarized the surface areas and pore volumes obtained for the catalysts by N2-physisorption measurements (Figure S1). Compared to the bare γ-Al2O3 support (202 m2/g; 0.51 cm3/g), lower surface areas and pore volumes were displayed by the obtained catalysts probably related to the presence of non-porous metal particles and the partial coverage of the support pores by the impregnated metals [25]. The iron presence seemed to result in slightly larger pore volume decrements. 3.2 Catalytic performance for CO-PROX reaction Fig. 1 shows the CO-PROX performance exhibited by the catalyst series evaluated at 120 L/gh. The CO conversion values increased with the temperature due to the favoured O2 surface coverages. Besides, the ca. 30% higher conversion values observed over the lower temperature range when Cu metal is incorporated into the bare Pt catalyst could be related to the favoured O2 dissociation processes often described for Cu-Pt based systems. With respect bare Pt/Al sample, the iron promoter results in improved CO conversion values especially at the higher temperatures. The behaviour of Fe/Pt/Al catalysts might be explained from the intrinsic activity recognized for Fe metal towards the Water Gas Shift reaction at relatively higher temperatures [26,27]. The combination of Cu and Fe promoters into the Pt/Al catalysts resulted in dramatically boosted CO oxidation rates achieving close to 100% conversions within temperatures between 100 and 150 °C. The conversion drops observed within the higher temperatures might be related to the relevance of the Reverse Water Gas Shift reaction (RWGS, CO2 + H2 = CO2 + H2O). 3.3 Catalytic behaviour of Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst The performance exhibited by the trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst was evaluated under different λ, i.e. different O2 to CO ratios. Fig. 2 A shows the increment of the CO conversion values attained with higher λ value. Still, the excess of oxygen also resulted in depleted CO2 selectivity´s i.e., the higher amounts of oxygen favoured both the CO and H2 oxidation. Besides, the lower CO conversions attained by the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst compared to those exhibited in Fig. 1 were associated to the lower H2O percentages. The effect of the water concentration in the reaction feed stream was also evaluated (Fig. 2B). The promotion on the CO-PROX activity observed in presence of water has been associated to favoured Water Gas Shift reactions and enhanced oxidation rates provided by the larger concentration of OH groups attained over the catalyst surface [28,29]. Furthermore, the promotional effect of provided water species has been related to the constitution of thermally instable reaction intermediates. Thus, the transformation of carbonate intermediates into bicarbonate species occurring in presence of water would facilitate the intermediate decomposition into CO and H2 hence promoting the overall reaction rate [29–31]. Fig. 2C shows the stability displayed by Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst evaluated at different temperatures and 120 L/gh. In agreement with the light-off exhibited by the catalysts series, larger CO conversion rates along with lower CO2 selectivity were observed as the temperature increased. For all tested temperatures, Cu-Fe/Pt/Al catalysts exhibited optimal stabilities with no variations in terms of conversion rates nor selectivity's. Fairly stable performances were shown by the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts during ca. 120 h (Figure S2). The scalability of the preparation of the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst was evaluated by increasing 5 times the amount of catalysts prepared by batch. In this sense, Fig. 2D shows catalytic activity exhibited by the Cu-Fe/Pt/Al catalyst when it was prepared in batches of 5 and 25 g. The equal performances obtained for both samples highlight the catalysts reproducibility and the suitability of the synthesis method for being applied at higher scales. 3.3 In-situ XRD in H2 presence as a function of the temperature The diffractograms obtained for all as-prepared catalysts (Figure S3) exhibited the diffraction lines characteristic of the γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 00–050–0741) support. The high dispersion and low content of Pt and Fe metals resulted in no diffraction lines associated to these metals in none of the samples. For the Cu containing samples, the characteristic diffraction lines of CuO with comparable crystalline domains were discerned (Table S1). The structural changes occurred in the catalysts in H2 presence as a function of the temperature were evaluated by in-situ XRD technique (Fig. 3 ). All samples exhibited the characteristic diffraction lines of the γ-Al2O3 support while the high dispersion and low content of Pt and Fe species hindered the observation of diffraction peaks associated to Pt and Fe metals during the XRD analysis. Fig. 3A and 3B show the XRD diffractograms obtained in the 38–45° 2θ range for Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al samples when exposed to H2 atmospheres as a function of the temperature. Thus, the progressive decrease of the CuO diffraction peak along with the simultaneous rise of Cu0 lines evidenced the CuO → Cu0 reduction in H2 presence as the temperature reached 200 °C. No significant CuO reductions were discerned at 200 °C for none of the catalysts. Interestingly, the larger exposure times required for the evolution of Cu0 lines along with the small CuO diffraction line observed for the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst after the entire reductive treatment suggesting a higher resilience of the trimetallic catalyst towards the total reduction. Fig. 3C compares the XRD diffractograms observed for all catalysts after the H2 reduction treatment where, as above described, no signs of Pt nor Fe oxides were discerned. Table 2 shows the Cu° crystal sizes estimated by Scherrer's equation for the Cu-containing reduced samples. Compared to Cu/Pt/Al sample, the slightly lower Cu° crystalline domains estimated for the trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst suggested that the iron incorporation might hinder to some extent the Cu° crystal growth. Furthermore, the absence of peak shifts during the reduction treatment suggested that no Pt-Cu solid solution were constituted for Cu/Pt/Al nor Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts [32]. 3.4 TEM analysis Fig. 4 shows the TEM micrographs obtained for the reduced Pt/Al, Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts. Morphologically, all catalysts revealed the constitution of nearly spherical particles with sizes ranging between 0.3–2 nm. Comparable outcomes were established by Kugai et al. [20] stating that not important variations of particle sizes were observed for 10%Pt-90%Cu o 90%Cu-10%Pt bimetallic systems. Similarly, Jain et al. [13] argued that the incorporation of a second metal oxide (Fe, Co, Cu) did not resulted in meaningful Pt sizes variations. For Fe-Cu/Pt/Al sample, the chemical analysis of the surface nanoparticles (exemplified in Figure S4) showed that most of the particles contained Cu-Pt and Cu-Fe-Pt particles with various atomic ratios. The small particle size observed for the Cu-Pt intermetallic compounds agrees with the XRD diffraction data where no clear signs of Pt-Cu alloy structures were identified since they are below the XRD detection limit. From the XRD and TEM results, the catalysts surface could be envisaged as highly dispersed (0.3 nm) Pt, (1–2 nm) Pt-Cu particles and Pt-Cu-Fe nanoparticles combined with some larger Cu agglomerates. The comparable particle sizes displayed by all catalysts rules out particle sizes related issues for the obtained outcomes. 3.5 CO adsorption analysed by FTIR spectroscopy In-situ FTIR spectroscopy using CO as a probe molecule permit the identification of the nature of the adsorbed species over catalytic surfaces free of remaining impurities thanks to a conjugated thermal and under vacuum pre-treatment [23]. The evolution of the IR spectra upon increasing the CO adsorbed amounts revealed the preferential interaction sites established between CO molecules and the different catalyst surfaces. Fig. 5 shows the evolution of the 2300–1700 cm−1 region during the CO adsorption at room temperature over the pre-reduced catalysts in H2 presence at 200 °C. For Pt/Al sample, the CO adsorption resulted in the evolution of an intense band centred at 2060 cm−1 associated to carbonyl species lineally adsorbed over Pt metal centres (Pt0-CO species). As CO coverage increases, this bands shifts up to 2066 cm−1 due to dipole-dipole coupling of CO adsorbed molecules. The observed band shift agrees with shifts associated to CO dipole coupling reported somewhere else . Moreover, the band located at 2085 cm−1 was observed at considerably CO coverages and should be associated to dimers or trimers Pt(CO)2 or Pt(CO)3 34,35. For Fe/Pt/Al catalyst, the band ascribed to lineal Pt0-CO species is initially observed at 2052 cm−1 and shifts up to 2060 cm−1 as the CO dosing proceed. Compared to the band positions observed for Pt0-CO species in Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, the lower wavenumbers at which the carbonyl band appears reflects the higher electron density over Pt metal sites achieved through the Fe incorporation [20]. The band observed around 1815 cm−1 was attributed to bridged Pt0-CO species. Moreover, a band located around 2246 cm−1, only discerned at high CO coverages, and could be associated to dimers/trimers or carbonyl species associated to partially oxidized Pt metal sites. With respect the bare Pt/Al system, the presence of Cu in Fe-Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts (Fig. 5C and 5D, respectively) resulted in significantly different CO-surface interactions. The different CO vibration frequencies observed should be ascribed to variations on the oxidation state, particle size and atomic coordination of metal atoms [35]. Thus, in presence of Cu metal, bimodal CO adsorptions over Pt and Cu sites with modulated electron densities were discerned. For Fe-Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts, no bridged Cu-CO species were observed. The CO adsorption over Cu/Pt/Al catalyst resulted in bands located at 2018 and 2024 cm−1 associated to Pt0-CO species along with bands attributed to Cu0-CO species (2100 cm−1) and Cuδ+-CO (2117 y 2134 cm−1)[18,36]. Therefore, the different contributions observed within both adsorption bands remarks the presence of CO adsorption sites with different oxidation states attained in Cu presence. The different electron density sites agree with the TEM analysis where isolated Cu and bimetallic Cu-Pt particles with various molar ratios were observed. Similarly to Fe/Pt/Al catalyst, the relatively lower vibration frequencies observed for Pt-CO species in the trimetallic catalyst reflects the larger electron densities achieved in Pt metal particles due to Cu → Pt electron donation. In agreement with the larger electron densities exhibited by Pt sites, the lower electron density displayed by the Cu atoms conforming Pt-Cu bimetallic particles accounts for the relatively high frequencies at which the Cu-CO and Cuδ+-CO species appear[37]. For Cu-CO bands, the observed shifts towards lower wavenumber as the CO coverage increased should be also related to the Pt-Cu interaction. Thus, the sigma electron density donated from CO to Cu particles is subsequently delocalized over close interacting Pt particles and result in promoted electron retrodonation (from Pt to Cu) increasing the electron density over Cu sites. Furthermore, the evolution of the carbonyl bands remark that the CO adsorption take places preferentially over the Pt or Pt-Cu particles. Once Pt sites are saturated, bands associated to isolated Cu metal sites were evolved being those located at higher wavenumbers. This agrees with the findings established by Rodriguez et al. [38] for Cu/Pt (110) catalysts where isolated carbonyls over Cu species (2120 cm−1) were not constituted until coverage values above 0.44ML were attained over bimetallic Pt/Cu single crystals. The favoured CO adsorptions over Pt surfaces can be explained indeed from the higher CO adsorption heats estimated for Pt surfaces (90 kJ/mol) compared to Cu metal sites (70–40 kJ/mol) 39. Comparable spectra were obtained for Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts. For trimetallic sample, bands associated to Pt0-CO species were observed at 2018 y 1996 cm−1 whilst Cuδ+-CO bands appeared at 2130, 2117 and Cu0-CO at 2100 cm−1. For Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al samples, the iron addition resulted in less intense Pt-CO species bands which at the same time appeared at lower wavenumber indicating superior electron densities. Besides, the Fe incorporation resulted in variations on the bimodal distributions associated to carbonyl species developed over Cu surfaces (Cu-CO). Thus, from the two contributions constituting the Cu-CO band, the higher-electron density Cu species became significantly more important in presence of Fe. From the integration of Pt and Cu carbonyl bands, the Pt and Cu metal dispersions of the reduced catalysts were estimated following the methodology proposed by Binet et al. [40] where the υ(CO) band intensity increment is plotted as a function of the dosed CO molecules. Assuming stoichiometry 1 for Pt:CO and Cu:CO, the metal dispersion was estimated from the number of CO molecules required for saturating each metal surface. The quantitative analysis of the amount of CO adsorbed over the catalyst surfaces is shown in Table 2. Comparable total CO amounts were absorbed for the Pt/Al and Cu/Pt/Al catalysts whilst the presence of iron in the Fe/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts resulted in significantly lower amounts. Thus, the similar amounts of CO molecules adsorbed over Cu sites in Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts resulted in comparable Cu dispersions. On the contrary, the significantly depleted CO molecules adsorbed over the Pt particles in iron presence suggested that iron atoms interacting with Pt particles hinders the ability of Pt sites for adsorbing CO molecules. Overall, the incorporation of Fe and Cu oxides into the Pt/Al catalysts resulted in the constitution of Pt centres exhibiting higher electron densities. The enhanced catalyst behaviour observed for all promoted catalysts respect the bare Pt/Al catalyst could be then related to the promoted O2 activation processes enabled and weaker Pt-CO interactions achieved in presence of Cu metal most likely due to the generation of Pt-Cu intermetallic compounds. For Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalysts, the presence of bimetallic Pt-Cu alloys resulted in bimodal carbonyl adsorption bands for Pt and Cu metals exhibiting, respectively, lower and higher electron densities. The addition of small amount of Fe resulted in further increments in the electron density achieved over Cu and Pt metal sites. Remarkably, the significantly lower CO adsorptions over Pt metal surfaces observed in presence of Fe suggest that Fe atoms block CO adsorption sites most likely by covering Pt sites due to the weakened CO adsorption. Comparable outcomes were described by Zhang et al. for Pt Fe nanoalloys who also ascribed the promotional effects of Fe species to efficient activation of O2 species over Fe surfaces[41]. In this work, despite the Cu-Fe solid solution was not evident from XRD data, the improvement observed in the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst behaviour should be related to the lower CO adsorption capacities and the variations on the metals electron densities. This points to a cooperative effect attained by combining Cu-Fe metals over Pt/Al2O3 which indorse the O2 adsorption by depleting the CO oxidation capacity. 3.6 H2-TPR of the prepared samples The reducibility of the samples was evaluated by H2-TPR (Fig. 6 ). A priori, the reduction processes occurring in the samples should involve the reduction of PtO, CuO and Fe2O3. Thus, the Pt/Al sample exhibited a reduction profile in which the PtO reduction takes place around 199 °C underlining a strong metal support interaction. In the case of Fe/Pt/Al sample, the reduction profile showed a wide peak between 150 and 350 °C with a maximum located around 246 °C. The reduction of Fe species[42–45] is often described sequentially with the reduction of Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → Fe0 with these reductions taking place at 290–312 °C and 400–650 °C, respectively. For the studied samples, the low Fe content inhibits discerning in a clear manner the sequence of the Fe reduction process. The Cu/Pt/Al sample presented typical reduction profile of a CuO catalyst with relatively large particles[46] with a single broad reduction peak located centred at 271 °C. For the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al sample, the reduction profile becomes narrower and the maximum shifts towards lower temperatures. The differences observed between the bimetallic and trimetallic system could be associated to variations on the particles size or modified metal support interactions. Besides, the H2 consumption were quantified assuming all reducible species at their higher oxidation state (Pt2+, Cu2+ and Fe3+). The Pt/Al sample exhibited ca. 5 times higher H2 consumptions than the theoretical expected assuming all Pt species as Pt2+. Such higher H2 overconsumption should be associated to rests of the organic precursors employed during the synthesis of the catalysts which are not totally removed during the calcination step due to the relatively low temperature (300 °C). Although comparatively lower than the Pt/Al sample, H2 overconsumption above 100% was also noticed for the Fe/Pt/Al sample. The lower overconsumption might be related to the reduction behaviour described by Wimmers et al[45] who argued hindered H2 diffusions were described for partially reduced oxides. 3.7 Operando FTIR characterisation of the catalyst surface Once the nature of CO adsorbed species was elucidated and in order to understand the different catalytic performances exhibited by the catalysts, the species constituted over the catalysts’ surface as a function of the temperature were evaluated by operando FTIR spectroscopy. Probably due the fact that the catalysts were pre-activated under reaction atmospheres, the species present over the pre-activated catalyst surface were mostly maintained during the entire experiment suggesting that no significant variations on the reaction pathway happened within the evaluated temperature range. Fig. 7 shows the spectra obtained for the Pt/Al, Cu/Pt/Al and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al samples as a function of the temperature for the different wavelength regions: 3100–2850 cm−1 (Fig. 7A), 2150–1750 cm−1 (Fig. 7B) and 1700–1000 cm−1 (Figure7C). Thus, the activated Pt/Al sample exhibited bands attributed to carbonate species located at 1585, 1570, 1476 and 1269 cm−1 [47,48]. The presence CO2 in the reaction mixture might result in the constitution of thermally stable carbonate like species [49]. The bands placed at 1618, 1420 and 1287 cm−1 were ascribed to bicarbonate species while the bands placed at 1375 and 1233 cm−1 were associated to formate species [36,50]. Within the 3100–2850 cm−1 region, bands located at 2967, 2924, 2902 and 2870 cm−1 were ascribed to υ(CH) stretching bands associated to the H-containing species. In presence of H2, Komatsu et al. [36] also distinguished the constitution of H-containing species for Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. Furthermore, bands placed at 2070, 2053 and 2030 cm−1 were associated to Pt-CO species with Pt sites exhibiting different electronic densities. As the temperature increased, the bands initially present at ca. 1585 cm−1 most likely related to poly-dentate carbonate species disappeared [51]. Besides, bands associated to formate species also decreased most likely due to their lower thermal stability [52]. Within the higher temperatures where the Pt/Al catalyst exhibited the higher conversion values, the catalyst surface appeared mostly covered by carbonate and bicarbonate species. With respect bare Pt/Al catalyst, the evolution of the FTIR-spectra depicted by the Cu/Pt/Al sample suggested that the incorporation of Cu indeed resulted in significant variations concerning the surface species constituted on the catalyst surface. Thus, the Cu/Pt/Al sample exhibited bands associated to Cu-CO and Pt-CO species placed at 2101 and 2011 cm−1. Once again, the lower wavenumber at which the Pt-carbonyl bands appear relates to the larger electron densities achieved over Pt surfaces through the Pt-Cu interaction. Besides, prominent bands located at 1577, 1456 and 1261 cm−1 related to carbonate like species were discerned. With significantly lower intensities, bands associated to formate (1375 and 1233 cm−1) and bicarbonate (1605 and 1420 cm−1) species were also evolved within the intermediate temperatures while decreased in intensity at the higher temperatures. Exhibiting an analogous trend, the υ(CH) bands discerned in the 3100–2850 cm−1 region were also associated to bicarbonates and formate species. Compared with Pt/Al catalyst, Cu/Pt/Al catalyst showed significantly more intense bands associated to carbonate species dominating the catalyst surface during the entire temperature window. Within the carbonyl region (Fig. 7B), the activated Fe-Cu/Pt/Al sample showed wider Pt carbonyl band with maximum at 2037 and 2009 cm−1. Compared to the Cu/Pt/Al catalyst, Pt-CO bands appeared at higher wavenumbers while comparable positions were observed for Cu-CO species. The lower band Pt-CO intensities displayed by the trimetallic catalyst suggested that Fe particles seems to affect mainly the electron density of Pt particles. In well agreement with the in-situ CO adsorptions, the constricted ability of adsorbing CO molecules could be correlated to the further decreased Pt electron densities and corroborates that Fe species should be mostly associated to Pt particles. At the highest temperature (200 °C), the Pt-CO band shifted significantly towards lower wavenumber which might be associated to the partial reduction of Pt species in presence of H2. Furthermore, compared to the Cu/Pt/Al, the iron incorporation resulted in less intense bands associated to carbonate like species (1592 and 1456 cm−1). As the temperature increases, larger relative intensities were discerned for bicarbonate (1524 and 1415 cm−1) and formate bands (1379–1390 cm−1). Compared to Cu/Pt/Al system which surface was mainly governed by carbonate species, noticeably higher amounts of H-containing intermediate species were developed on the trimetallic catalyst. The promotional role of H2O/H2 on the CO-PROX conversion rate has been quite established [8,53] over a variety of metal supported catalysts. According to Tanaka et al. [17], the enhancement of the CO oxidation performance observed FeOx/Pt/TiO2 catalysts was attributed to the active role of H2O species and proposed a reaction pathway with hydroxyl‑carbonyl and bicarbonates species as main reaction intermediates. The improved catalyst performances obtained for the trimetallic catalyst could indeed be related to the benefits attained through the Pt-Cu intermetallic structures along with the larger amounts of formates and bicarbonates species which, being characterized by lower thermal stabilities, might facilitate the intermediates decomposition into the reaction products and account for the improved catalyst performance displayed by the trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this work, the excellent catalytic performance displayed by a trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst under realistic reforming atmospheres for CO-PROX reaction has been evidenced. The systematic evaluation of Pt/Al2O3, Cu/Pt Al2O3 and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts enabled the elucidation of the role played by the different metals establishing meaningful relationships between catalytic behaviour and reaction mechanism. With respect bare Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, the improved performances attained by Pt/Cu/Al2O3 catalyst was attributed to the larger electron densities attained over Pt sites and the active role of Cu species towards the O2 adsorption processes. The subsequent incorporation of small amounts of Fe species resulted in boosted catalyst behaviours within the lower temperature ranges. The characterisation results indicated that for the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, the addition of Fe resulted in further superior electron densities over Cu-Pt particles. The inhibited CO adsorption processes achieved in presence of Fe over the Pt nanoparticles resulted in improved CO-PROX performances and suggested that Fe species were mostly interacting with Pt metal. Remarkably, FTIR operando spectroscopy evidenced different surface species constituted over the catalysts surface. Under reaction atmospheres, the bimetallic Cu/Pt/Al2O3 exhibited surfaces dominated by carbonate species while the Fe incorporation entailed the constitution of significantly larger H-containing surface species. The enhanced abilities for developing thermally instable intermediates favoured by small amounts of Fe could indeed account for the improved catalysts performances displayed by the trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: This work proposes a trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst as an appealing system for preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) reaction. The excellent conversion rates achieved by the Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts under realistic reforming-surrogated feed streams along with the catalyst stability, reproducibility, and scalability showcase a very competitive system for CO-PROX reaction units. Furthermore, the systematic analysis conducted for Pt/Al2O3, Cu/Pt Al2O3, and Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts enabled establishing meaningful relationships between catalytic behaviour and the catalyst surface to reactants interactions. Thus, the enhanced CO oxidation performances attained by the incorporation of Fe species into bimetallic Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were associated to superior surface electron densities and inhibited CO adsorption process over Pt surfaces. Remarkably, operando-DRIFTS spectroscopy evidenced significantly larger H-containing surface species developed over the trimetallic system. The enhanced abilities for developing thermally instable intermediates favoured by small amounts of Fe should indeed determine the enhanced catalysts behaviours displayed by the trimetallic Fe-Cu/Pt/Al2O3 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Unravelling the role of Fe in trimetallic Fe-Cu-Pt/Al2O3 catalysts for CO-PROX reaction
